awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: Using Roll Call Votes to Understand Legislative Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
In most democracies, the public record of legislative votes in national and local parliaments is an important basis for holding elected officials accountable. In political science, that record is also an important source of data on legislator and party behavior. In practice, many legislatures create a public record of the votes cast by individual legislators for only a fraction of the issues on which votes occur. These recorded votes often are not a representative sample of all votes cast and may exhibit systematic biases that have implications for political accountability and for the science of political behavior. Therefore, understanding the characteristics of the issues that receive a publicly recorded vote (a roll-call vote) is essential to our understanding of democratic processes and evaluating the limits of scientific inferences that can be drawn from roll-call data. This study will advance our understanding of the voting record through examination of national parliamentary bodies around the world.

Intellectual merit. Currently in political science, two accounts, derived from alternative political motivations, serve as the basis of contending explanations of the decision to conduct a recorded vote: disciplining arguments and position-taking arguments. This study (a) develops theory about the implications of these accounts and specifies testable propositions about both what issues come to a vote and what are the consequences for legislators' observable voting patterns; (b) examines the policy domains and legislative sponsors in the full population of votes to the policy domains and legislative sponsors subject to recorded votes; (c) examines the formal rules and political context that condition the issues that receive a recorded or unrecorded vote; and (d) generates and estimates statistical models that account for the effect of expected outcomes on the decision to request a recorded vote.

In doing so, the study provides a deeper understanding of the roll-call vote data generating process than political science has had to date, which, in turn, will allow stronger inferences to be drawn from observed voting behavior.

Broader impact. This study is the first systematic effort to understand the roll-call vote data generating process for multiple national parliaments. The study will advance our understanding of democratic representation, accountability, and responsiveness.  In addition, it will provide a large corpus of data on parliamentary voting that will be important to scholars in the field of comparative legislative politics. Finally, the project will provide graduate students with invaluable research experience.

por.por_cntn:
Roll-call votes play an important role in democratic politics and the study of it.  They provide a record of elected representatives’ legislative behavior, which may be of value to voters, interest groups, party elites, and academic researchers. We use these vote results to measure the preferences of individual representatives, the cohesiveness of political parties, the polarization of the party system and a host of other quantities of interest.  However, the exit to which roll-call votes facilitate monitoring by any principal (voters or otherwise) or the extent to which they allow use to accurately capture these other aspects of representation depends crucially on the quality of the picture they present of legislative behavior. Many legislatures record only a fraction of their votes by roll call.  In these settings, the sample properties of the roll-call vote record will determine whether the picture of legislative behavior seen by principals is accurate and can be used effectively to portray legislative behavior. Our project describes the properties of roll calls as a sample of all votes, develops theories of when the process will be strategically invoked, and (will ultimately) test the observable implications of those theories. Preliminary results indicate that in many national contexts we should be very concerned about using roll-call votes without considering how they, as a sample of all votes taken (or decisions made), were generated. Where legislators have a choice about how a vote will be taken, which is the case in most legislatures, actors will strategically decide when to record the votes of individual representatives and when to record only the aggregated outcome of a vote. In a sample of 58 chambers, we found that 43 chambers do not define roll call as the standard operating procedure and that 37 chambers do not require the use of roll call on votes of final passage of legislation.

In theoretical terms, we start by trying to understand the selection of votes for public record. We develop two arguments. One is that it is done so that party leaders can hold their party membership accountable for how they vote (in order to enforce party discipline). The other is that it is done to position-take with the public. Parties want to publicize votes that raise their electoral prospects and that diminish the prospects of their opponents. The arguments have different implications for when we will see roll-call votes and the properties of those votes. To investigate the validity of these arguments, we have assembled legislative minutes of a wide variety of countries around the world. Using advanced computer science techniques we are able to use those minutes to statistically test what drives use of roll-call votes. From this we can draw conclusions about how effective roll-call votes are for monitoring elected officials.

We have two initial findings. First, the two arguments we develop are novel. While they are predicated on conventional wisdom about the motivations for roll-call votes, their implications defy that conventional wisdom. For example, if parties are motivated by position-taking, then we should always see roll-call votes under typical conditions. In a sample of six countries, we found that roll calls constituted anywhere from 0.5% to 56.3% of the voting record. This variation suggests there is more to the story than simply that motivation. Second, our data collection reveals that for many legislatures the selection issue is substantial; large shares of legislative decisions go unrecorded.
